docs.lead_paragraph: LETTER FROM THE BARL OF SHAFTKOBURY. To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: I have just read in your paper a letter purporting to be the reply of the American ladies to the address of the " Women of England," on the subject of Slavery in the United States.

headline.main: ENGLAND.; The Aberdeen Cabinet--The Income Tax--Meeting in Behalf of the Madiais--Lord Shaftesbury--Lord John Russell as Editor--Miscellaneous.

docs.lead_paragraph: The members of the ABERDEEN Cabinet seem, individually and collectively, gifted with what old TALLEYRAND used to call "a great talent for silence," seeing that ever since the reelections, a job safely got with the exception of Mr. SADLIER, who, being a mere Lord of the Treasury, does not reckon for much, not a word has escaped them touching the future policy of the Government. byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: ANOTHER ACCIDENT FROM BURNING FLUID.--On Sunday evening, about 9 1/2 o'clock, Mrs. BUCKNELL, boarding house keeper, No. 546 Houston street, was badly burned in the face and hands by the explosion of a fluid lamp.
docs.snippet: ANOTHER ACCIDENT FROM BURNING FLUID.--On Sunday evening, about 9 1/2 o'clock, Mrs. BUCKNELL, boarding house keeper, No. 546 Houston street, was badly burned in the face and hands by the explosion of a fluid lamp.
